IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8235 S1381-1169(11)00388-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2011.09.021 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Distributions of the number of active centers determined by quenching and fractionation. Fig. 2 Molecular weight distribution curves of poly(1-hexene) and poly(1-hexene-co-ethylene). Fig. 3 Changes of the propagation rate constant with the molecular weight of the fractions. Fig. 4 Polymerization activities of the Flory components in poly(1-hexene) and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymer. Fig. 5 Relations of polymer isotacticity and ethylene incorporation rate with the molecular weight. Table 1 Effect of ethylene on the number of active centers in 1-hexene polymerization. Effects of ethylene as comonomer on the active center distribution of 1-hexene polymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts Zhiqiang Fan a ⁎ Letian Zhang b Shengjie Xia a Zhisheng Fu a a MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China b Shanghai Research Institute of Chemical Industry, Shanghai 200062, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 571 87952400. Graphical abstract The effects of ethylene on the active center distribution of 1-hexene polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2−Al(C2H5)3 catalyst were studied by counting the number of active centers in polymer fractions of different molecular weight. The results disclose differences of catalytic properties between the multiple active centers and correlations between their kinetic parameters. Highlights ► 1-Hexene is polymerized with TiCl4/MgCl2–Al(C2H5)3 catalyst. ► Active center distribution is studied by counting active centers in polymer fractions. ► Effects of adding ethylene on the active center distribution are studied. ► Ethylene increases active centers in the low molecular weight fractions. ► Ethylene increases k p value of the medium–high molecular weight fractions. 1-Hexene homopolymerization and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2–Al(C2H5)3 catalyst were compared to investigate the effect of ethylene on the distribution of active centers. The polymerizations were quenched with cinnamoyl chloride, and the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]) was determined by measuring the cinnamoyl group labeled on the propagation chains. Both polymer samples were fractionated into 9–10 fractions according to molecular weight, and [C*]/[Ti] in each fraction was also determined. Adding small amount of ethylene in 1-hexene polymerization markedly increased the number of active centers that produce low molecular weight polymer. This phenomenon agrees with the mechanism suggesting the presence of Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites and their activation by ethylene. The k p value of the newly emerging active centers in the copolymerization system is much lower than that of the homopolymerization system. In the copolymerization system, the active centers producing polymer chains of the second highest molecular weight and isotacticity show the highest k p value, while those producing polymer of the highest molecular weight and isotacticity show only the second highest k p. On the other hand, the active centers producing polymer with lower–middle chain length show the lowest ethylene incorporation rate. These results disclose differences of catalytic properties between the multiple active center types and correlations between their different kinetic parameters, which may lead to new understanding of the active centers and polymerization mechanism. Keywords Supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst 1-Hexene Ethylene Copolymerization Active center distribution Mechanism 1 Introduction MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts are predominant in the manufacture of polyolefins, accounting for about 90 million tons of polyolefin resins per year. Recent technology allows production of a half million tons of polyolefin per year in a single reactor at efficiency as high as 60kg polymer per gram catalyst. However, our knowledge of this kind of catalyst is still far from complete after almost 60years of studies. As a prominent character of heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts, their multiplicity of active centers has been recognized long ago [1–13], but the real distribution of active centers, namely, the number of each type of active center in the family of 3–7 type active centers, has scarcely been determined [13–15]. It has been fully understood that the broad molecular weight distribution (MWD) [1,7,10,11,13], chemical composition distribution (CCD) [16–20] and stereochemical diversity [4,12,14,15,21–23] of polyolefins synthesized with heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts are originated from the active center distribution. These chain structure distributions are origins of the different mechanical and processing properties of Ziegler–Natta polyolefins in comparison to polyolefins synthesized with single-site catalysts. Without the knowledge of active center distribution, it will be impossible to fully clarify the structure and chemical properties of the different active centers, and the efforts of improving polyolefin's properties through catalyst design will be greatly hindered. Determination of the number of active centers in a heterogeneous catalysis system has become the key step of a complete mechanistic study. When the number of different active centers that produce different products (in a catalyzed polymerization, they may be polymer chains of different molecular weight or chemical compositions) can be determined, a complete description of the active center distribution can also be made. However, only very limited research work has been devoted to the experimental study of active center distribution of MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts [13–15], owing to lack of suitable methods of counting the active centers that produce different polymer chains [24]. Bukatov et al. studied the distribution of active centers among three polypropylene fractions of different stereoregularities prepared with several MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts using the method of 14CO inhibition of the polymerization [14]. In a previous work of our laboratory, we studied the distribution of active centers with respect to molecular weight of poly(1-octene) synthesized with a simple TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst using a method of quenching the polymerization by acetyl chloride [13]. Through such studies, not only the number of different active centers is determined, but also their chain propagation constants, chain transfer (or termination) and stereochemical parameters are deduced by combining the results of active center counting and polymerization kinetics investigation. With this body of knowledge, the catalysis mechanism of different types of active centers can be explored and depicted quantitatively. In our recent work, we improved the method of active center counting by using cinnamoyl chloride as a quenching reagent and determined the total number of active centers in 1-hexene homopolymerization and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts [25]. It was found that addition of ethylene in 1-hexene polymerization system caused a nearly three-fold increase of active center concentration accompanying increase in polymerization activity. We tentatively explained this phenomenon as presence of Ti–CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites and their activation by insertion of an ethylene as the following reactions (where POL means a polymer chain): (1) Activation of α-olefin polymerization by ethylene in heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysis systems has been reported in many literatures [26–33]. Strong activation of ethylene on propylene polymerization with homogeneous catalysts has also been found [34–37]. This activation effect has been explained as releasing of Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer type dormant active sites by insertion of an ethylene [28–31]: (2) The rate constant of propylene insertion in the Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer bond has been proved to be much lower than that of propylene insertion into the Ti–CH2CH(CH3)–Polymer bond, but the insertion of ethylene in the Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer bond is still very fast to ensure effective activation of the dormant sites [29]. Kissin and Rishina proposed the presence of Ti–CH(CH3)2 type dormant sites in heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysis systems to account for the results of propylene–ethylene copolymerization under a high hydrogen concentration [32,38] and a series of olefin kinetical phenomena. This type of dormant sites can also be released by ethylene insertion. Therefore, in propylene polymerization there might exist two kinds of dormant sites that respond to addition of ethylene differently. For the Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer type dormant sites, if they can be labeled with cinnamoyl group through the cinnamoyl chloride quenching experiment, ethylene addition will not cause increase of the active center concentration, but the rate propagation constant should be higher for the activation effect. For the Ti–CH(CH3)2 or Ti–CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites, the products of their reaction with cinnamoyl chloride will be washed away in the polymer work-up process, and thus will not be counted into the number of active centers. When they are activated by ethylene and turned into Ti–Polymer (active propagation center), they will be included in the active center counting. Our previous results support the presence of Ti–CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites. However, the remaining question is: are the Ti–CH(C4H9)–Polymer type active sites formed in 1-hexene polymerization also dormant sites? Though they have steric congestion similar to or even larger than the Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer type dormant sites, which may strongly hinder the insertion of 1-hexene, they may not be stabilized by the β-agostic interaction between Ti and the β-methyl in the Ti–CH(CH3)–Polymer species. This difference might greatly reduce the degree of dormancy in the Ti–CH(C4H9)–Polymer type active sites. In this work, the effects of ethylene as a comonomer on the active center distribution of 1-hexene polymerization with a TiCl4/MgCl2–triethylaluminium catalyst system are studied by fractionating the polymer according to molecular weight and counting the number of active centers in each fraction after quenching the polymerization with cinnamoyl chloride. By comparing the active center distribution of 1-hexene homopolymerization and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization, the mechanism of ethylene activation effect and the differences of activation effects among different active centers are explored with more solid experimental evidence. What is more, the correlations of propagation rate constants of different active centers with their copolymerization ability and stereoselectivity are also studied, which show interesting characteristics of the active centers that has not been observed before. As described in our previous work [25], we used 1-hexene as the main monomer, not the industrially more important propylene, because poly(1-hexene) and its copolymer with small amount of ethylene are soluble at room temperature, thus becoming suitable for counting the active center by UV–vis spectrometry. 1-Hexene has also been extensively applied as monomer in the studies of polymerization kinetics and mechanism with homogeneous catalysts [39–45]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Polymerization and active center counting A simple TiCl4/MgCl2 supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst was prepared through reaction of MgCl2·nEtOH adduct with TiCl4. The preparation procedures and characterization of the catalyst have been described in a previous work [46]. The Ti content of the catalyst determined by spectrophotometry method is 8.2%. Al(C2H5)3 (TEA) was purchased from Albemarle Co. and diluted in n-heptane before use. 1-Hexene (98%) was purchased from ACROS Organics, and purified by refluxing over metal Na for 6h and distilled before use. Cinnamoyl chloride (98%) was purchased from Alfa Aesar Co. and diluted with n-heptane to 1M before use. Ethylene (polymerization grade product of SINOPEC Shanghai Petrochemical Co., Ltd.) was further purified by passing through a column filled with de-oxygen reagent and molecular sieves. 1-Hexene polymerization or 1-hexene/ethylene copolymerization was conducted in a 500mL Schlenk flask equipped with magnetic stirrer under the protection of pure nitrogen (99.999%). The flask was first evacuated and filled with 1atm nitrogen, and immersed in a 40°C oil bath during the reaction. The reagents were added in the order of solvent, 1-hexene, TEA, and the catalyst was added at last to start the polymerization after stirring the solution for 10min. In the copolymerization experiment, before addition of the catalyst, the flask filled with 1atm nitrogen was connected through a Φ3mm tubing with a metal cylinder containing ethylene of 1.1atm. This allows the ethylene flow from the cylinder to the flask to reach an 0.1atm equilibrium partial pressure of ethylene in the flask. During the copolymerization ethylene gas was continuously supplied to the flask to maintain the total pressure at 1.1atm and ethylene partial pressure at 0.1atm. The total volume of liquid phase in the two polymerization runs was 300mL. After 6min of polymerization at 40°C, cinnamoyl chloride (in cinnamoyl chloride/Al (molar ratio)=3:1) was injected into the reactor to quench the polymerization. After 10min of quenching reaction, isopropyl alcohol/hydrochloric acid (200:1, v/v) mixture was added to decompose the catalyst, cocatalyst and cinnamoyl chloride, and the polymer was precipitated with excess of isopropyl alcohol. The polymer after thorough purification was dried in vacuum at 60°C. 2.12g and 2.72g polymers were synthesized in the 1-hexene homopolymerization and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization runs, respectively. Content of carbonyl in the quenched polymers was determined spectrophotometrically with a Varian Cary 100 Bio UV-Vis spectrometer, using n-heptane as the solvent. The calibration curve for quantitative determination of carbonyl content has been made in our previous work [25]. As proved in our previous work, each propagation chain existing in the system at the time of quenching is labeled with a carbonyl group after the quenching reaction, thus the number of carbonyl corresponds to the number of active centers [25]. 2.2 Polymer fractionation Conventional method of precipitation fractionation has been adopted to fractionate the two polymer samples according to molecular weight. About 2g polymer sample was dissolved in 250mL n-heptane in a 500mL flask that has a small sag at the bottom and immersed in a thermostatic bath set at 30°C. After stabilizing at 30°C for 30min, isopropanol was slowly dropped into the flask with vigorous stirring, until the solution become milky. Raise the temperature to 35°C and the solution became transparent again. Then slowly cool the solution to 30°C and kept for 24h. During this period the solution was separated into two phases: a dense phase deposited in the sag at the bottom of the flask and the dilute phase over it. The dense phase (concentrated polymer solution) was separated from the dilute phase using a syringe and injected into excess isopropanol to precipitate the first polymer fraction. The fraction was then dried in vacuum at 60°C for 12h and weighed in an analytical balance. For the dilute phase in the flask immersed in the 30°C thermostatic bath, the operations of precipitant addition, phase separation and fraction recovery were repeated in the same way as the first fraction, until the dilute phase contained no more polymer. 9 and 10 fractions of different molecular weight were separated from the poly(1-hexene) and poly(1-hexene-co-ethylene) sample, respectively. The total recovery rate of the fractionation processes was 98%. GPC curves of all the fractions were measured to obtain their molecular weight and polydispersity index (PDI) data. 2.3 Polymer characterization The molecular weight distribution curves of the polymer samples and their fractions were measured with a PL 220 GPC instrument (Polymer Laboratories Ltd.) at 30°C in THF. Three PL mixed-B columns (500–107) were used. Universal calibration against narrow polystyrene standards was adopted. The 13C NMR (75MHz) spectra of the copolymer were recorded at 40°C on a Varian mercury 300 plus NMR spectrometer. 100mg of sample was dissolved in 0.5mL of deuteriated chloroform (CDCl3), and ∼2mg chromium(III) acetylacetonate was added to shorten the relaxation. Instrument conditions were as follows: pulse angle=90°, pulse delay time 5s, acquisition time 0.8s, spectral width=8000Hz. Five thousand scans were taken with the Waltz-16 decoupling method. The signal for the first methylene carbon of the butyl branch was used to quantify the isotacticity of poly(1-hexene) segments at the pentad level [47,48]. The signal of isotactic pentad “mmmm” is located at 34.8ppm, and those of the irregular pentads and “rrrr” pentad are located in the range of 33.8–34.7 [47,48]. The fraction of isotactic pentad ([mmmm] %) is calculated from the ratio of peak integrations of 34.9–34.7ppm and 34.9–33.8ppm. Ethylene contents of the original copolymerization product and its fractions were determined from the 13C NMR spectra according to the assignments and calculation method reported in the literature [49,50]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Active center distribution A 1-hexene homopolymerization and a 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization run was conducted at 40°C with a TiCl4/MgCl2–TEA catalyst system containing no electron donor. The TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst has been prepared by reaction of MgCl2·nEtOH adduct with TiCl4 as described in our previous work [46]. To obtain a copolymer that is soluble in n-heptane at room temperature, only small amount of ethylene (P E =0.1atm) was used in the copolymerization. The good solubility of the copolymer will also ensure low mass transfer limitations in the polymerization reaction. Both polymerization runs were quenched with cinnamoyl chloride after 6min reaction, and the active center concentration was determined by counting the cinnamoyl group in the polymer with UV–vis spectrometry [25]. The molecular weight, content of isotactic poly(1-hexene) pentad segments and ethylene content of the copolymer were also determined. Table 1 shows the results of polymerization and polymer characterization. It is clear that this catalyst system showed activation effect of ethylene on the polymerization. The copolymerization activity was ∼50% higher than the homopolymerization, even though only 3.1% ethylene was incorporated. This comonomer effect should not be related to mass transfer limitations, as both the homopolymer and copolymer are soluble in the polymerization medium. Meanwhile, the number of active centers was more than doubled by adding ethylene, leading to a decrease in average k p value of ∼33%. In comparison to the k p values (15–19L/mols) of 1-hexene polymerization catalyzed by [rac-(C2H4(1-indenyl)2)ZrMe][MeB(C6F5)3] contact ion-pair at 50°C and [Hexene]=0.15–1.5M [40], the k p value (30L/mols) of 1-hexene polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2–TEA at 40°C and [Hexene]=1.0M is slightly higher. As mentioned in Section 1, increase of the total active center number with ethylene addition may be explained by the reactions of Eq. (1), but the dormancy of Ti−CH(C4H9)−Polymer type active sites and their activation by ethylene (Eq. (2)) still need to be verified. To solve this problem, the two polymer samples were fractionated by conventional precipitation fractionation into 9 and 10 fractions, respectively. The fractionation was strictly according to molecular weight, with the weight average molecular weight of the homopolymer fractions ranging from 2.3×104 to 2.3×106 and that of the copolymer fractions from 3.5×104 to 2.1×106, and the polydispersity index of the fractions ranging from 1.3 to 2.3. The fractionation results are listed in Table 2 . The number of active centers in each fraction was determined, and the numerical distribution of active centers with respect to the molecular weight of the fraction was drawn using a method similar to the Schulz–Dinlinger procedure that is used to treat the data of polymer fractionation. Fig. 1 shows the active center distribution of the homopolymerization and copolymerization systems. It is seen that adding small amount of ethylene in the 1-hexene polymerization system resulted in dramatic increase of active centers in low molecular weight section (log M <5.0). These newly emerging active centers might originate from the Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites when they are activated by ethylene [32,38]. The number of active centers in the fractions of medium molecular weight (5.0<log M <5.7) was slightly increased by ethylene addition, and the active centers in the high molecular weight section are not increased. This means that the Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites are mainly formed by Ti species that have high chain transfer rates when they are turned into propagation centers. As shown in Fig. 2 , the MWD of the polymer is only slightly changed by introducing ethylene, meaning that the remarkable increase of active centers in the low molecular weight section has not caused extra increase of polymer fractions in this section. Based on the number of active centers and polymerization activity of each fraction, the chain propagation constants (k p) of the homopolymer and copolymer fractions, representing the intrinsic activity of their active centers, were calculated. Fig. 3 shows the changes of k p with molecular weight of the polymer fractions. Seeing that both the polymerization rate (R p) and active center distribution may change with the polymerization time [19], the data of k p in Fig. 3 are actually average values over the polymerization duration of 6min. At the initial stage of polymerization, an induction period may be observed, in which the total number of active centers and the active center distribution change rapidly with time [51]. This will be studied in our future works. It is quite interesting to observe the changes of k p with molecular weight and the effects of ethylene on the k p value. In the homopolymerization system, the k p value increases with log M in a nearly monotonous way, and two plateaus of k p appear at log M =4.8–4.6 and log M =5.7–6.4. This reminds us the similar reactivity distribution of active centers in 1-octene polymerization catalyzed by TiCl4/MgCl2–Al(CH2CH3)3 reported in our previous work [13]. Increase of k p value with the polymer molecular weight has also been reported in other literature [15]. When small amount of ethylene was introduced, the k p value of the low molecular weight fractions (log M <5.2) was evidently lowered. Because the total number of active centers of these fractions are remarkably increased by ethylene addition, it is reasonable to ascribe the lower k p values to emerging of “new” active centers with even lower k p value in these fractions. For the fractions with medium to high molecular weight (5.3<log M <5.7), the k p values of the copolymerization system become higher than that of the homopolymer. The largest increment of k p value appeared at log M =5.6, where the number of active centers in the copolymer was almost the same as in the homopolymer. It is thus natural to ascribe this k p increment to activation of active centers originally present in the homopolymerization system. This fact may be taken as evidence supporting the dormancy of Ti−CH(C4H9)−Polymer type active sites and their activation by ethylene according to Eq. (2). In the copolymer fraction of the highest molecular weight, the k p value dropped down for almost 40% from the maximum point. This is, to our knowledge, the first observation of decreasing intrinsic activity of active center with increasing molecular weight. The mechanism of this peculiar phenomenon will be discussed later in this article. To further investigate the influences of ethylene comonomer on the active center distribution, the molecular weight distribution curves of the two polymer samples were deconvoluted into 5 Flory components (I, II, III, IV, and V), respectively. The qualities of the deconvolutions are satisfactory. This kind of deconvolution has been proved a useful and reliable method to differentiate the multiple active sites of heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts [10,11,13,19,20]. Each Flory components represent a type of active centers that produce polymer with special molecular weight and Schulz–Flory MWD. The weight fraction and average molecular weight of the Flory components in the two samples are listed in Table 3 . Comparing the molecular weight of the Flory components with that of polymer fractions of precipitational fractionation (Figs. 1 and 3), we can say that the fractions of log M =4.4–5.2 roughly correspond to the Flory components I and II, the fractions of log M =5.2–5.7 correspond to the Flory components III, and the fractions of log M =5.7–6.4 correspond to the Flory components IV and V. The polymerization activities of the different active centers were calculated by multiplying the weight fraction of a Flory component by the total activity of polymerization, and are compared in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4 shows that activity of all the Flory components were increased by ethylene addition, but the Flory components III and IV were increased to a higher extent than the other components. It is clear that ethylene plays the role of increasing the polymerization rate in all the active centers. Judging by comparing Fig. 4 with Figs. 1 and 3, the increases of I and II in the copolymerization system can be largely explained by increase of active center number, while the increases of III and IV should be the results of real activation effects, namely, enhancement of intrinsic activity. The situation of Flory component V seems to be different from the rest four. It is not so sensitive to ethylene addition, as neither the number nor the intrinsic activity of its active centers was evidently changed. 3.2 Chain structure distribution The correlation between the micro isotacticity of the polymer fractions with their molecular weight is shown in Fig. 5 . The percentage of isotactic poly(1-hexene) pentad segments ([mmmm] %) of both the homopolymer and copolymer samples increase almost linearly with the molecular weight. Similar correlation of polymer isotacticity with molecular weight has been reported in the literatures [52–55]. For fractions with the same molecular weight, the microisotacticity of the copolymer fractions is always slightly lower than the homopolymer fractions, possibly because of the intervention of ethylene units in the poly(1-hexene) segments. The proportional correlation of isotacticity with log M may be interpreted as similar effects of spacial congestion in active centers on the chain transfer reaction rate and the stereoselectivity. Therefore, it can be said that active centers with more congested stereochemical structure produce polymer with higher stereoregularity and higher molecular weight. Inspired by this concept, we recognized that the decrease of k p value with increasing molecular weight in the range of log M =5.6–6.4 (see Fig. 4) might be related with the simultaneous increase of spacial congestion in the active center. It is reasonable to think that highly congested space in the active center is beneficial to controlling the stereochemistry of monomer insertion, but may on the other hand increase the steric barriers to the monomer coordination and insertion steps. For the active centers with low isospecificity, namely, the centers producing low molecular weight polymer, though they have low spacial congestion that is beneficial to high k p value, higher frequencies of 2,1-insertion and chain transfer reactions may strongly interrupt the chain propagation process, leading to low intrinsic activity. Only those active centers that have both medium spacial congestion and low frequencies of 2,1-insertion and chain transfer reactions can reach the highest intrinsic activity. The variations of ethylene content of the copolymer fractions with the molecular weight (also depicted in Fig. 5) are somewhat strange. As the molecular weight of the fraction decreased from 3×106 to ∼1×105, the ethylene content slowly decreased from 3.2% to 2.7%, but when the molecular weight decreased further to 3.5×104, the ethylene content rose again and finally reached 3.5%, the highest value among all the fractions. These differences in ethylene content are comparable to the experimental errors, so it is difficult to make reliable explanations. Summarizing the above mentioned experimental results and mechanistic considerations, we can tentatively divide the active centers of the catalysis system into four groups in the order of decreasing molecular weight, and estimated values of their characteristic parameters are listed in Table 4 . According to Table 4, the first group of active centers accounts for only 3–6% of all the active centers and produces polymer with the highest isotacticity and molecular weight, but shows only the second highest intrinsic activity. 2,1-Insertions of α-olefin in this group of active centers has a very low probability, so their number and intrinsic activity are only slightly influenced by ethylene; the second group has a larger number and the highest intrinsic activity, but 2,1-insertions of α-olefin happen in a higher rate, leading to a large increment of polymer yield and k p by ethylene addition; the third group accounts for 30–50% of the active centers, but has much lower k p value than the first and second groups; the fourth group of active centers are mainly present in Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant state in the 1-hexene homopolymerization system, but can be activated by ethylene. This group has the largest population but the lowest k p value, even much lower than that of the third group of active centers. This leads to only moderate increase of the yield of low molecular weight fractions. Its high tendency to be halted in Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant state may be caused by the high chain transfer rate, as this type of dormant species can be formed by either chain transfer to monomer or secondary insertion of 1-hexene into Ti−H bond, as shown in the following equations [24]: (3) (4) The Ti−H bond may be formed by β-H eliminations in active and dormant Ti−P or Ti−R species. Judging by the increase of total active center number after ethylene addition (see Table 1), the fraction of Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites in the system may be estimated to be ∼60% of all the active centers. However, since the Ti−CH(C4H9)−Polymer type dormant sites are also included in the counted number of active centers, and the average k p value of the system would also change with the activation of Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites, the fraction of Ti−CH(C4H9)−Polymer type dormant sites cannot be estimated by comparing the k p values of the homopolymerization and copolymerization systems [14]. This problem may be solved by combining the method used in this work with other research approaches. 4 Conclusions In 1-hexene polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2−Al(CH2CH3)3 catalyst, the distribution of active centers with respect to the polymer molecular weight strongly inclines to the low molecular weight side, while the intrinsic activity (k p) of active centers producing low molecular weight polymer is much lower than those producing high molecular weight polymer. Adding small amount of ethylene in 1-hexene polymerization exerted strong effects on the active center distribution of TiCl4/MgCl2−Al(CH2CH3)3 catalyst system. The number of active centers that produce low molecular weight polymer (M <1×105) is markedly increased after introducing ethylene. This phenomenon agrees well with the mechanism suggesting the presence of Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites and their activation by ethylene. The intrinsic activity of the newly emerging active centers in the 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization system is much lower than k p of the active centers in the 1-hexene homopolymerization system. In the copolymerization system, where dormant active sites cannot be accumulated, the active centers producing polymer chains of the second highest molecular weight and isotacticity show the highest k p value, while the active centers producing polymer of the highest molecular weight and isotacticity show only the second highest k p value. In other words, the highest chain propagation rate constant of a certain type of active center in the catalyst does not ensure formation of the longest polymer chains. Polymer chains of the highest molecular weight are formed at moderate propagation rate by active centers with the highest stereoselectivity. On the other hand, the active centers producing polymer with lower–middle chain length show the lowest ethylene incorporation rate, implying that both strong stereochemical congestion in the active center and frequent stagnation of the active centers in dormant states will make the insertion of α-olefin more unfavorable than that of ethylene. The information of active center distributions, namely the number and kinetic parameters of different types of active centers, may greatly facilitate in-depth understanding of the catalysis mechanism and exploration for improved catalysts. coredata.dc:description: 1-Hexene homopolymerization and 1-hexene–ethylene copolymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2–Al(C2H5)3 catalyst were compared to investigate the effect of ethylene on the distribution of active centers. The polymerizations were quenched with cinnamoyl chloride, and the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]) was determined by measuring the cinnamoyl group labeled on the propagation chains. Both polymer samples were fractionated into 9–10 fractions according to molecular weight, and [C*]/[Ti] in each fraction was also determined. Adding small amount of ethylene in 1-hexene polymerization markedly increased the number of active centers that produce low molecular weight polymer. This phenomenon agrees with the mechanism suggesting the presence of Ti−CH(CH3)(CH2)3CH3 type dormant sites and their activation by ethylene. The k p value of the newly emerging active centers in the copolymerization system is much lower than that of the homopolymerization system. In the copolymerization system, the active centers producing polymer chains of the second highest molecular weight and isotacticity show the highest k p value, while those producing polymer of the highest molecular weight and isotacticity show only the second highest k p. On the other hand, the active centers producing polymer with lower–middle chain length show the lowest ethylene incorporation rate. These results disclose differences of catalytic properties between the multiple active center types and correlations between their different kinetic parameters, which may lead to new understanding of the active centers and polymerization mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of ethylene as comonomer on the active center distribution of 1-hexene polymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts
